job_title: SOAR Case Manager in Austin, TX
pros: I really enjoyed working at IC, the staff was always really supportive.
cons: I wished that had more PTO

job_title: Relief Residential Assistant Safe Haven in Austin, TX
pros: It is a place where you can get great hands-on experience working with a protected population. Relaxed environment with great supportive co-workers, and easy to accomplish the work within the time allowed for your shift.
cons: I would recommend a person to have thick skin in order to work here. The population you are serving can be difficult to manage at times. Must be able to look past the surface of a situation and show compassion regardless of the client's attitude.

pros: Get to work in the community and help individuals. Coworkers are great. Good benefits/time off. Never boring.
cons: Management is severely undertrained and often taken from departments that do not know how the job they manage works. Management changes frequently and is heavy handed about their approach to how the team should be. Most recent management change resulted in a 120% turnover (including a new hire who left immediately after being hired d/t having issues with being lied to by management about role/schedule) and 5 other senior staff leaving. Schedules that were promised and adhered to for years were thrown out the window, management would frequently become hostile when questioned or concerns were brought up, team members were talked about by management in negative ways constantly to incoming employees and other managers/HR (regardless of no writeups ever occurring) and a variety of concerns far too numerous to cover on this platform. HR is seemingly complicit in this as, despite an entire team departing, no changes have been made and concerns continue to be shared by others still within the organization.

pros: Rewarding work, great colleagues and will learn alot
cons: Not enough money for the work

pros: The benefits and trainings were good.
cons: The Salary could be higher no doubt for the amount of work.

pros: Great team, dedicated therapists who care about clients
cons: Unreasonable paperwork expectations and billing expectations

pros: i like the flexibility of the role with you in control on of your schedule
cons: can be overwhelming once caseload starts growing

pros: great supervisors flexible communication great pay reimburse miles
cons: can be draining at times a lot of paper to stay organize

pros: Great people to be friends with
cons: Does not pay enough for the amount of work you do

review_title: Community Agency that serves the most vulnerable
job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker LCSW in Austin, TX
pros: Allow for 36 hour week Get floating holiday hours. Lots of holidays Opportunity to work with the most vulnerable population.
cons: Understaffed, normally work over hours, HR complicated.

job_title: PASRR Service Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: benefits, time off, remote work
cons: caseload too high leadership isn’t the best, wouldn’t recommend. but it is okay for an entry level position working in mental health. pay isn’t great but not horrible.

review_title: Good place to get started; terrible place to stay long term
job_title: QUALIFIED MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONAL in Austin, TX
pros: It's a great way to get your hours if you're trying to get licensed, and a good place to get into the mental health space for the first time.
cons: The hours are long, the bureaucracy is terrible, and the pay is laughable. The only way I was able to make ends meet on their salary was to consistently work over 40 hours. Don't worry, if you complain long enough and taking a verbal beating from their clients repeatedly, maybe the board will feel bad one week and throw you a pizza party for lunch.

pros: The team I worked with was great, and everyone was friendly and supportive.
cons: The company as a whole does little to help or support their employees. In the 8 months I worked there we had goodbye parties for 8 employees (including my own). I worked under 3 separate supervisors in 8 months. The retention rate and burnout is terrible and such a high turnover rate makes it difficult to successfully run the program, and the effects show, and the clients suffer for it. Upper management did nothing about it and there seems to be a large disconnect between them and the "boots on the ground." I didn't even have an exit interview. There is no way to move up in the company without a masters. Do not work here, there are companies that offer more pay, less stress, and more benefits.

pros: Enjoyed fast paced environment on the crisis team. Great co workers.
cons: Low pay, and no room for negotiating pay when I worked there.

pros: Flexible, good team, I feel recognized and supported
cons: Pay is not the best

pros: Benefits, PTO and work culture are good. I even feel the salary is fair, I didn't expect to make this much after just 1 year of being an RD.
cons: Disorganized management, not much direction when being asked to complete projects. I am a dietitian, so working in mental health I am frequently pushed outside the scope of my practice without feeling supported or comfortable in these situations.

pros: Your co-workers will be awesome - dedicated, compassionate, and willing to go above and beyond for both clients and colleagues.
cons: Executive management is utterly hostile to employees. Middle management is largely supportive but they have no power to improve the lot of their employees, and get in trouble for advocating for front-line staff. The pay is below what you'd make in the private sector, but the bigger problem is that executive management believes that staff is disposable - they pay lip service, but don't do anything about the obscene amount of staff turnover (they don't have to deal with any of the problems it causes). The CEO in particular has been flat-out lying to staff about the union drive that is currently happening at the agency, to the point that it insults the intelligence of the employees.

pros: It is only recently they bumped up their pay,
cons:
You are overworked and not allowed to do overtime and yet you're expected to get everything done regardless
Not alot of room to really go up in the organization unless you are willing to continue working on your education and reach a masters and even doctorates to be able to move up

pros: No weekends, PTO, great benefits
cons: Manager is horrible and micro manager

pros: Great work environment. Management cares about employees.
cons: It's a non profit so pay may not be commensurate with what you do but you do it anyways cos you love what you do.

pros: Wonderful coworkers, tons of CEU opportunities, lots of experience
cons: Offensively low pay, not much support, impossible performance expectations

job_title: Licensed Practitioner of Healing Arts (LPHA) in Austin, TX
pros: You get great experience working with a difficult client population, and the clients do make the work worth it if you enjoy what you do. I have met some amazing people who work alongside me, and have also met some amazing management staff. The pay isn't terrible once you're fully licensed. PTO, sick, and discretionary time are all offered. It is possible to engage in really fulfilling work with clients, despite other setbacks.
cons: No room to provide honest feedback to upper management about client contacts, how to improve client experiences, and how to improve staff experiences. Productivity is put above all. If you're fully licensed and have been for a while, you will outgrow the pay unless you want to be a supervisor or lead, in which case you need to be prepared to work long hours and overextend yourself as this seems to be what the norm is with management I've seen. Lots of staff, if they've been there for a while, engaging in direct client contact, are burnt out- not just because of the difficulty of this work but because apart from pushing EAP and "self-care", staff mental health is not prioritized above productivity. I've had many clients discuss frustration with being "tossed around" Integral Care as a system, not receiving genuine, good quality care, and lots of this has to do with staff not being paid enough, staff not being valued enough, and staff all around have little room to provide feedback and have their voice heard. It's a large agency- keep that in mind.

review_title: Satisfaction is based on your boss
pros: So much to learn from really good psychiatrists. The clients are fascinating on so many levels.
cons: Upper management plays favorites. Your job satisfaction depends on your manager!!!! Not sure about other clinics but our new supervisor screams Green and lacks experience+ wisdom for the diverse clientele. Her personality is controlling. Her leadership style to micromanage. Most of us are looking for another job.

pros: Medical providers are paid well, but social workers are not. PTO is adequate.
cons: Work environment is awful. Critical aspects of your job are ordered instead of discussed and agreed upon like respectful adults. Treated like a productivity machine rather than a human.

pros: Good benefits package, that's it.
cons: Terrible management, no sense of organization. They will train you on new information that they haven't even look at themselves. Training is always a waste of time. They only care about billing as many clients as possible vs providing good quality care to your clients. You will hear constantly how many contacts you need to have. It's a good starting job, but please do yourself a favor, do not come to this place unless you are having a hard time finding a job. You will be UNDERPAID and UNAPPRECIATED. Management only talks to you when they need you to fix something, otherwise they don't care how much you'll be doing for your clients.

review_title: Quality of Job Dependent Upon Leadership
job_title: HCS Service Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: The initial benefits package was great. It was then changed to one with a high deductible.
cons: Job quality impacted by poor management. HR was not helpful in mitigating managerial misconduct.

review_title: If you're under bad management, RUN!
pros: Free health insurance premium plans, pays more than some other agencies for similar work, accrued time off.
cons: This agency is the fast track to burn out city, especially for new professionals. They rope you in with their higher salaries and health insurance, then become a slave to a system that does not work and when it doesn't work, you get blamed and assigned more work. You will be primarily working with the underserved and underprivileged, which isn't for the faint of heart in a city like Austin that takes 0 responsibility for the homelessness issue and lack of funding for services that are desperately needed. Turnover is always high and it doubled/tripled during the year of 2020 and 2021. I worked there for over 6 years under two managers who were verbally and emotionally abusive, and there is no oversight to correct the actions of upper management. Complaints fall on deaf ears and have done so for years. I have some colleagues that are happy under their management that still work there, sadly for me it was the opposite experience. They can't keep prescribers, can't work out how to actually provide effective services to clients and change within the agency moves at a turtle's pace. Got really tired of spinning my wheels for years trying to implement change, burning myself out and being abused and used for it all. Also, if you are hired and decide you don't like your boss, you can't move positions for 6 months and managers routinely throw people under the bus who are looking at other positions in the agency so that the new manager is unlikely to hire them, due to the high turnover and massive amount of time and energy it takes to hire and train new staff. Salaries are not negotiable, which is good in terms of assuring that everyone earns the same salary regardless of gender/race etc, but it does limit your ability to make more money due to this. I wouldn't go back if they called me right now and doubled my salary.

job_title: Crisis Intervention Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: Supportive team members, paid time off, flexible schedule
cons: Overworked, not enough pay, and way too many expectations in aa limited amount of time for crisis.

pros: They are working hard to take inclusion and equity to the next level. There are several committees designed to look at different aspects of the culture and work environment. Genuinely caring group of people.
cons: Productivity metrics and ways to work quickly and efficiently don't always leave room for staff to be fully present with clients.

pros: Opportunities for growth and learning. Teams tend to be highly supportive. Competitive pay. Mileage reimbursement offered. Supervision opportunities available as well.
cons: Upper management is very out of touch. I’ve been with the company for 5 years and the CEO absolutely does not know my name. The “boots on the ground” employees can barely pay rent.

review_title: Altruism only takes you so far
job_title: Crisis Specialist QMHP in Austin, TX
pros: The job itself is rewarding. Most co-workers are supportive and good to work with.
cons: Overall compensation is terrible. The agency does not care about employees as much as they like to make it seem. They will not listen to your concerns and make excuses for it. Management can be a joke and there are power hungry people in these roles with no finesse or ability to effectively lead. Challenge them one time and they will go after you. There is such high turnover due to the company culture being terrible and low pay. Any benefits pale in comparison to the cons.

pros: I had an amazing supervisor, very supportive environment, lots of training opportunities
cons: Heavy on paperwork, need strong organizational skills

job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker LCSW in Austin, TX
pros: Large company, smart people, well funded
cons: Slow moving company bureaucracy , politics

review_title: Please implement information from employee based surveys
job_title: Licensed Practitioner of Healing Arts (LPHA) in Austin, TX
pros: Benefit package. Direct management and team are great.
cons:
Limited counseling based positions. Rushed directives from upper management that does not consider employee adjustment and patient's engagement.

High productivity metrics at time not aligned with quality care.


Limited work life balance while on shift, 30 min break not really supported or acknowledged for community based work when clients live on different areas of Travis County.

pros: Pay, Potluck, Coworkers, Overtime, Down time when it’s not busy
cons: Management could be indifferent at sometimes

pros: Diverse and good work culture.
cons: They do not offer competitive compensation and the cost of living in Austin is HIGH.

pros: exciting work environment; wonderful team
cons: bureaobstacle course; staff under-appreciated; static policies

review_title: You take the good with the bad
job_title: School Based Therapist in Austin, TX
pros: Great teams and managers, supportive environment, flexibility in schedule (within schools schedules), independent work environment, opportunities for training, diverse population in backgrounds and presenting issues
cons: Impossible amounts of paperwork and high expectations for billing and productivity by the agency, isolated from other clinicians, high rate of burnout, big organization that doesn’t implement change at its core to stop burning people out (although the school teams are awesome at doing what they can)

review_title: Good Starting Job After Grad School
pros: Flexible, great supervisor, great benefits
cons: The population you work with is difficult. Working with the homeless population, and not be able to guarantee them housing is hard. It can be heartbreaking not being able to fully help people/

job_title: QUALIFIED MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONAL in Austin, TX
pros: Pays case managers higher than other places. The benefits are very affordable and some plans are completely paid for by the employer. Good entry level experience. The ability to move teams and not remain stagnant in your position.
cons: Mid level pay for a professional degree. Quick turnover.

pros: Agency accepts feedback from employees and makes changes.
cons: I have no complaints at this time.

job_title: Customer Care Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: You feel like you are helping people
cons: Way underfunded to meet the needs of the community. Understaffed

job_title: Mental Health Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: trainings, benefits, culture group s
cons: discrimination, master's degree for promotions

pros: Because of the pandemic employees are able to work from home
cons: The downside of working for this company is that there is not a lot of growth potential or flexibility with salary

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Austin, TX
pros: good benefits, good experience, good clinical supervision
cons: high caseload, unrealistic paperwork expectations which constantly change

job_title: Enhanced Community Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: Flexible schedule, minimal supervision, direct interaction with clients, exposure to other community based resources
cons: lack of management support, at times there was no solution to provider inability to support clients

pros: Great coworkers and consumers. Inclusive environment.
cons: Huge caseload. High turnover. Too many meetings that could have been emails.

pros: Client-centered, high integrity, great pay.
cons: high number of clients in caseload

pros: Benefits are very nice here
cons: Promotions based on who you know

pros: Supportive team, decent pay, moving to a new building (so they have said for a year)
cons: Understaffed, constant protocol changes, technical issues, no opportunities for growth, callers can be abusive

job_title: Mobile Crisis Outreach Team in Austin, TX
pros: ATCIC is a great place to work if you enjoy working with adults and children with chronic and persistent mental illness and can deal with management issues. I got great experience working individually with clients, and met many great people at ATCIC.
cons:
I worked in the Crisis Services Division. Entry level management and team leads are openly hostile toward staff and engage in unprofessional behaviors (talking with other staff about confidential information, favoritism, etc). There is constant turn over and management don't take employee seriously. Disciplinary levels are handed down to staff routinely and often without any real evidence. On my old team, over half of the team of veteran staff were on disciplinary levels at once and every member of the team was given a level over the course of 1-2 years.  The MCOT and PES teams have both had a quick near 100% mass exodus over in the past 1-2 years. I felt the MCOT team was very chaotic  and poorly managed. I eventually left because I felt like our team was poorly managed, disorganized, providing sub standard services. I felt like staying at ATCIC would have been a professional liability (I know several of my colleagues felt the same way and we all left).

Regarding management- Good managers are run out of their position by upper management. Management often have little to know management experience and are all friends. It's like a mean girls club. HR workers do their best, but they are ineffective due to structural issues. They have very little ability to make change in the organization.

pros: people, benefits , mission, rewarding work
cons: pay, work life balance, provider burnout

review_title: good experience for a first job, but not a good place to stay
job_title: Case Manager In Crisis Services in Austin, TX
pros: Because it serves such a large number of people with so many diverse and overlapping problems, this agency provides a great opportunity to learn about mental illness and how to help people navigate social service systems. Many of the other case managers I worked with were very knowledgeable and passionate about their jobs, and I found most of my colleagues to be professional considering the amount of stress we were under.
cons: Turnover is high even at the upper management levels. It's not uncommon to find yourself suddently without a supervisor or moved to a different department because managers or funding sources have changed. When I expressed concern about my workload, I was retaliated against and ultimately ended up quitting.

review_title: Working in the Mental Health Field
pros: Working at ATCMHMR was a positive experience in that one is able to provide social services to clientele who benefit greatly from a structured, experienced support system. Family and friends are often unavailable or suffer from burn out and cannot effectively support the client in achieving and maintaining optimal functioning and health in the community. The knowledge base and contacts available at ATCMHMR are extensive even though funding for mental health treatment has historically been insufficient to meet the needs of the community.
cons: Turnover of staff is high, pay for social work is low, and the stress of attempting to manage medications, treatment, and problem behaviors can become overwhelming when programs are undermanned and underfunded.

job_title: Intensive Case Manager in Austin, TX
pros: I have been working at Integral Care for a year and a half now, and I am pretty satisfied with my experience thus far. My program manager and team lead are incredibly supportive of me and of the unit (Child & Family Department) as a whole. I feel supported and heard and encouraged by managers but coworkers alike. This position has also given me invaluable experience - it's a program I'm proud to be a part of.
cons: The job itself can be quite stressful, but if you love to help people then this is a great position to leap into the world of social work. That aside, having to adapt to the constantly changing procedures and standards in the department can be a lot to manage. However, the positive is that the department has seen many improvements over the time I've been here, which is quite fortunate for new-comers.

pros: Benefits.  Experience with severely mentally ill individuals.  The divisions vary greatly and there is some ability to move around, but that can be hindered by management.
cons: I worked in two different divisions. Psychiatric Emergency Services was run poorly and the management was punitive.  Management seemed to intentionally keep an atmosphere of chaos by not supporting any chain of command.  Middle management set up situations to assure a bad outcome resulting in disciplinary action if an employee was being targeted.  Unfortunately, this happened to one person or another almost continuously.

job_title: HCS Service Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: You can quickly earn vacation time.  Vacation and Sick time are kept separate.  I shared an office with two other individuals and the personality dynamic was great.  My supervisor was supportive of my work.  One year I received a bonus.
cons: There is not room for advancement.  The pay was very low, which is why I left.  This was a very top heavy company.  The second year of employment, I did not receive a bonus, but the CEO received a 10 K bonus approved by the board.

pros: There is nothing good about politics unless you are running for office. Unfortunately, what seem like a great job became the most stressful job ever, and I didn't even know how stressed I really was until, I had a panic attack. The job I loved very much had taken a toll on me.
cons: Most people say that they don't, do politics they do and it's a terrible think that happens. Just trying to know who was who to those who were just out for blood was my second job.

review_title: Smells of lemon mop soap and fear...
pros: Salary, benefits, PTO, clients, cold water fountains
cons:
Malicious management is much more the rule than the exception at Integral Care, per my experience and what I witnessed happening to colleagues.  Bullying by supervisors is rampant.  

A cheaper-by-the-dozen ethos permeates this place. Clients were regularly referred to as "numbers."  And your "numbers" are often under scrutiny and outside of your control, no matter how much professional effort you put in.  One could work at Exxon Mobil for quadruple the pay and perhaps face less day-to-day mistreatment. I recommend not working here if you respect yourself enough not to be demeaned regularly. 

On a  positive note: I would like to thank Integral Care for leading me to the ultimate Zen path:  Walking away...

job_title: Psychosocial Rehabilitation Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: Benefit package offered is a plus. Upper management I worked under was fabulous, no micromanaging. If you are self-directed this is a good fit. Some positions offer an opportunity to get creative and work on interventions learned in post grad. ATCIC offers trainings and has an annual Training Day that allows employees the time to take off work, network, and sign up for workshops of interest.
cons: Bits of the agency are a bit disorganized. Starting salary is low and unless you have a clinical license pay will remain low. The PAP could be more helpful with in-office crises.

review_title: Good organization to work for if you're interested in admin.
pros: ATCIC pays their admin staff well, and there is a bilingual stipend available for some positions. The benefits are good and the majority of the staff are great to work with.
cons: When I found out what the case managers were making I was appalled. They are definitely underpaid, but that seems to be the case at most places.

pros: working to make community housing better for the homeless felt like a great reason to get up in the morning.
cons: I have nothing bad to say about ATCIC, truly was an experience that was more then I could have expected and I had an opportunity to give back instead of just making money or having a title.

job_title: LPHA for MCOT in Austin, TX
pros: The diverse population of all ages, demographics and psychiatric illness will provide good experience, especially for a new clinician. However, outside of the New Employee Orientation training held by HR, you will receive little to no training from Team Lead or Program Manager. Benefits are good in terms of PTO and agency contribution towards Health Savings Account. Schedule preferences were routinely granted, making it easier to save PTO (team works on a rotating schedule with different days off each week). If you can establish yourself with the passive-aggressive, catty management, you're likely to promote quickly. Front line staff was a joy to work with!
cons: United Healthcare Insurance is sub-par, however a high deductible policy is available with no monthly employee contribution.  No compensation for licensed clinicians working over 40 hours, although flex time is possible. Team Lead and Program Manager often provided misinformation regarding agency policies and showed questionable clinical judgment at times. The disrespect from management towards employees' boundaries regarding staying past end of shift was remarkable. This agency is not that different from others in terms of shortage in staffing and high workload. However, staff is treated as insignificant and when concerns are raised about the need for work/life balance, the Program Manager referred staff to EAP. What did stand out in comparison to other agencies was the hostility and condescension from management, blatant inconsistencies in expectations (discipline given to one, but not another for the same error), and lack of trust in staff. Management was routinely lacking in their ability to set example of the work ethic they demanded from staff. The punitive measures and utter lack of training by Team Lead and Program Manager is a poor example of leadership and will never be conducive to retaining qualified clinicians. To expect fairly new, unlicensed clinicians to provide training in the field is irresponsible. In my 15 years working for government agencies (10 years of which has been in mental health field), I have experienced a fair share of politics and difficult personalities, but MCOT management lowers the bar. Think twice before working for MCOT or EMCOT.

pros: Helping others understand there is always hope and the access to some of the most unique intelligent people on earth.  They can really bring out the best in you if you let them.
cons: Poor communication. Weird rules and out of date legacy process and policy.

review_title: Great benefits and somewhat flex schedule but a lot of paperwork and can be a stressful work place

Large pay raise when you are fully licensed as an LPC

cons:

Working with majority of peoples served can be stressful 
Location of offices

pros: Competitive pay, opportunities for advancement, good benefits, ongoing training, paid weekly educational leave, ability to work overtime with other units, serving populations in need, overall great experience for people who are new in the field!
cons: There are definitely some politics with upper level management in several divisions. Can't speak for every division though, but it's all about who you know!

review_title: Supervisor in the intellectual & developmental disabilities unit
pros: The benefits were great. The pay could have been better.
cons: The lack of training. All new hires went through a generic employee training.  There was no formal training for your unique position. the amount of work could not be completed in a 40 hour week. The unit did not have adequate operating procedures. Management allowed bullying and intimidation between employees which lead to a toxic work environment.

Institutionalized hypocrisy

cons: Some management issues and unrealistic productivity goals. The pay is not the best for all the work that has to be put in.

review_title: Depends on the program you work for

pros: Great management and sense of camaraderie within the team. Lots of opportunities for overtime, at least within my department
cons: No cons, I genuinely like my job. I mean, I wish it paid more, but I'd probably feel the same at any pay rate.

pros: It is exceedingly difficult to be fired from this organization, so job security is a potential benefit. Benefits are also pretty comprehensive and low cost.
cons: The entire organization lacks stability. You can be sure that you will have zero input regarding policy and procedure or workflow or any practical aspect of your job. Senior management lacks understanding about what it is like to be a service provider and expectations far exceed reality.

pros: Flexible work schedules during the week, Loved my clients
cons: Poor communication from management, Not enough transparency with performance measures

pros: Good, real world experience to gain clinical skills.
cons: Overloaded caseloads, underpaid, high level of stress daily, poor management and direction.

pros: You get a coffee cup as a bounes
cons: Not a great place to work unless you are lazy and if you willing  to put up with favoritism and races comments form office managers that are actually never there to work or help out. You will never get a raise and hard for you to move to a high position or expanding your experience do to poor management

pros: United HealthCare benefits, great support network.
cons: Not much communication between departments; senior level management is not in touch with "on the ground" employment

pros: Can be great depending upon leadership
cons: poor leadership can make a job you otherwise love feel impossible

pros: Opportunities for advancement, supportive supervisors, paid leave
